question: I'm a 36 year old male, 270 lbs, on a beta blocker for anxiety and intermittent high blood pressure.  My last doctor's visit (quarterly checkups) was about a week ago, with a 130/80 bp and a clean EKG.  I was stress tested last June, and had an echocardiogram (? . .  the test where they listen to your circulation) of my heart, arms and neck concurrently.  All tests were spectacularly negative.  My bloodwork is always clean -- no diabetes, and just a touch of high cholesterol that wavers in-and-out of norms by a hair.  But I seem to always retain a large amount of water in my left leg in particular.  Sometimes I even feel the fluid shifting en masse (or some other cramping) around my shin, ankle, top of foot, etc.  My loose-knit socks still leave a crimp in my shin or ankle, and over the past few days I've been noticing a background pain in my leg, slight reddening between the knee and ankle, and a slight blue-graying of my toenails.  I sit a long time at my job, although I do get up occasionally, and I walk two or three times a week, several miles each instance.  I've suggested CHF to my doctor, and he doesn't believe this to be the case.  A diuretic isn't practical, because I also have mild gout.  I plan on losing the weight and by and large I've been doing a good job, but there are relapses.  Is my condition reversible with constant, regular exercise and just a bit more preventative maintenance, or am I well on the path to permanent damage somewhere, whether the heart, legs, or what-have you?  As I said, I am an anxious person, and this mystery is causing me a great deal of stress.  Any input would be welcome.  Thanks in advance.
title: Edema, CHF, Diabetes, or N.O.T.Above?
